facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1962 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 402-D of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 30, 1962 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 402-D of 1962.

facts.text: Appellants were mortgagees of certain properties, including a house, on the basis of a mortgage-bond dated July 19, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were mortgagees of certain properties, including a house, on the basis of a, mortgage-bond dated July 19. 1928.

facts.text: Consideration of the mortgage bond was Rs. 25,000 and interest was provided at nine per cent per annum compoundable annually.

anchor.surface_text: The companysideration of the bond was Rs. 25,000 and interest was provided at nine per cent per annum companypoundable annually.

facts.text: One of the properties covered by the bond was sold to Bibi Chand Tara on October 23, 1937 subject to the earlier mortgage of 1928.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the properties companyered by the bond, one of the properties was sold to Bibi Chand Tara on October 23, 1937 subject to the earlier mortgage of 1928.

facts.text: In October 1949, Bibi Chand Tara was declared an evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: In October 1949, Bibi Chand Tara was declared an evacuee.

facts.text: In 1939 the appellant filed a suit against the original mortgagors and others including Bibi Chand Tara for the amount due under the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: In 1939 the appellant filed a suit against the orignal mortgagors and others including Bibi Chand Tara for the amount due under the mortgage.

facts.text: A preliminary decree was passed in their favour in March 1942.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary decree was passed in their favour in March 1942 and the final decree followed in April 1945.

facts.text: The final decree followed in April 1945.

anchor.surface_text: and the final decree followed in April 1945.

facts.text: Certain sums were received by the appellants before they had filed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that certain sums were received by the appellants before they had filed the suit.

facts.text: Certain other sums were also received after the preliminary and final decrees.

anchor.surface_text: Certain other sums were also received after the preliminary and final decrees.

facts.text: Certain Zamindari properties which were also included in the mortgage had been sold after the final decree and the money appropriated towards the decree.

anchor.surface_text: It further appears that certain Zamindari properties which were also included in the mortgage had been sold after the final decree and the money appropriated towards the decree.

facts.text: Another house which was also included in the mortgage bond was sold later and the sale money was again appropriated towards the decree.

anchor.surface_text: Another house which was also included in the mortgage bond was sold later and the sale money was again appropriated towards the decree.

facts.text: Appellants put the decree in execution in November 1952 against the house in dispute for a sum of Rs. 60,000 and odd.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually the appellants put the decree in execution in November 1952 against the house in dispute for a sum of Rs. 60,000 and odd,.

facts.text: There was a sale in that execution proceeding, but it was set aside on the application of the Assistant Custodian, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: There was a sale in that execution proceeding, but it was set aside on the application of the Assistant Custodian, Patna.

facts.text: Appellants made an application before the Assistant Custodian for the recovery of the mortgage money claimed by them, claim for Rs. 40,000 and odd.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellants made an application before the Assistant Custodian for the recovery of the mortgage money claimed by them. and in this application their claim was for Rs. 40.000 and. odd.

facts.text: This application was dismissed as it was filed before a wrong authority.

anchor.surface_text: This application was also dismissed as it was filed before a wrong authority.

facts.text: Appellants filed a claim for the same amount before the Competent Officer under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually the. appellants filed a claim for the same. amount before the Competent Officer under the Act inasmuch As the property in dispute was companyposite property

facts.text: The property in dispute was composite property in which the evacuee had mortgagor's interest while the appellants who are non-evacuees had mortgagee's interest which had ripened into a decree for sale.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch As the property in dispute was companyposite property in Which, the evacuee had mortgagors interest while the appellants who-are number-evacuees had mortgagees interest which had ripened into a decree for sale.

is the interpretation of s. 9 1 of the Evacuee Interest Separation Act, No. LXIV of 1951 hereinafter referred to as the Act . The question arises in this way.

anchor.surface_text: S. 9 1 which is in these terms Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any law or contract or any decree or order of a civil court or other authority, where the claim is made by a mortgagee, nonmortgaged property of an evacuee shall, subject to the provisions of subsection 2 be liable for the payment of interest at a rate exceeding five per cent per annum simple on the principal money advanced or deemed to have been advanced.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 2 d composite property inter alia means any property which, or any property in which an interest, has been declared to be evacuee property and in which the interest of the evacuee is subject to mortgage in any form in favour of a person, not being an evacuee.

Under s. 2 h , principal money in relation to a mortgage deed executed by an evacuee inter alia means in the case of mortgage deed which has not been executed by way of renewal of a prior mortgage deed, the sum of money advanced by way of loan at the time of the execution of the mortgage deed.

Under S. 3 the Act and the rules and orders made thereunder have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument having effect by virtue of any such law, save as otherwise expressly provided in the Act.

issues.text: The only question raised in this appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Punjab High Court is the interpretation of s. 9(1) of the Evacuee Interest (Separation) Act, No. LXIV of 1951

anchor.surface_text: The only question raised in this appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Punjab High Court is the interpretation of s. 9 1 of the Evacuee Interest Separation Act, No. LXIV of 1951 hereinafter referred to as the Act

issues.text: whether there is anything in the words of s. 9(1) which leads to the result that a mortgage transaction should be reopened from the date of the mortgage and accounts taken afresh and anything paid in excess of five per cent per annum simple interest applied towards reduction of the principal amount in the absence of a specific provision to that effect in the Act

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie therefore in the absence of such a provision it cannot be assumed that the legislature intended that a mortgage transaction should be reopened from the date of the mortgage and accounts taken afresh and anything paid in excess of five per cent per annum simple interest applied towards reduction of the principal amount. We have therefore to see whether there is anything in the words of s. 9 1 which leads to this result in the absence of a specific provision to that effect in the Act.

issues.text: whether the decree of a civil court is binding on the Competent Officer

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from a consideration of these provisions that the Competent Officer is bound by the decree of a civil court except an ex parte decree passed after August 14, 1947 in respect of a mortgage subject to the provisions of ss. 9 and 10.

issues.text: to what extent the provisions of s. 9(1) are retrospective

anchor.surface_text: The Competent Officer held that though the provisions of s. 9 1 were retrospective to a certain extent they could not be stretched to mean that if a mortgagee had already realised interest at a rate exceeding five per centum Per annum simple even before the Act came into force the excess would go to liquidate the principal amount proportionately.

issues.text: whether non-mortgaged property of an evacuee shall be liable for the payment of interest at a rate exceeding five per cent per annum simple on the principal money advanced or deemed to have been advanced

anchor.surface_text: S. 9 1 which is in these terms Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any law or contract or any decree or order of a civil court or other authority, where the claim is made by a mortgagee, nonmortgaged property of an evacuee shall, subject to the provisions of subsection 2 be liable for the payment of interest at a rate exceeding five per cent per annum simple on the principal money advanced or deemed to have been advanced.

arguments.claim: Appellants not entitled to interest higher than 5% per annum simple from date of mortgage; entire transaction must be reopened from mortgage date with excess receipts credited to principal

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal we are only. concerned with one ground based on s. 9 1 of the Act., The contention of the Custodian was that the appellants were not entitled to any interest higher than five per cent per annum simple from the date of the mortgage under s. 9 1 of the Act. Therefore the Custodian claimed that the entire transaction should be reopened from the date of the mortgage

arguments.claim: s.9(1) applies only to liability still due under mortgage; does not authorize reopening past accounts or recharacterizing past interest payments

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie therefore in the absence of such a provision it cannot be assumed that the legislature intended that a mortgage transaction should be reopened from the date of the mortgage and accounts taken afresh and anything paid in excess of five per cent per annum simple interest applied towards reduction of the principal amount.

arguments.claim: Key words 'non-mortgaged property shall be liable' indicate future/ongoing liability only

anchor.surface_text: The key words in the provision are nonmortgaged property shall be liable. These words indicate that the Competent Officer when he comes to deal with a liability under a mortgage must calculate this liability on the basis that interest should be allowed only on the principal amount and only at the rate of five per cent per annum simple.

Further from the date of the final decree also the appellants will be entitled to simple interest at the rate of five per cent per annum on the principal amount only.

holdings.text: The Competent Officer is bound by the decree of a civil court other than an ex parte decree passed after the 14th day of August, 1947 in respect of any matter which has been finally decided by such decree, subject to the provisions of sections 9 and 10.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from a consideration of these provisions that the Competent Officer is bound by the decree of a civil court except an ex parte decree passed after August 14, 1947 in respect of a mortgage subject to the provisions of ss. 9 and 10.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of proviso to s.8(3); harmonious construction with ss.9 and 10 overriding interest calculations.

holdings.text: Section 9(1) applies only to the liability still due under the mortgage and does not authorize reopening of past accounts or recharacterizing past interest payments exceeding 5% as principal reduction.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie therefore in the absence of such a provision it cannot be assumed that the legislature intended that a mortgage transaction should be reopened from the date of the mortgage and accounts taken afresh and anything paid in excess of five per cent per annum simple interest applied towards reduction of the principal amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of key words 'shall be liable'; absence of specific provision for reopening; non-obstante clause limited to ongoing liability.

holdings.text: Payments made before the date of the suit, if not exceeding the contractual rate of interest (even if above 5% simple), do not reduce the principal amount.

anchor.surface_text: Any amount paid before the date of the suit i.e. December 11, 1939, provided it is not more than the contractual rate of interest though it may be above five per cent per annum simple will not go to reduce the principal amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9(1) does not retroactively reopen pre-suit transactions; applies only to still-due liability.

holdings.text: From the date of the suit till the date of the final decree, the mortgagee is entitled only to simple interest at 5% per annum on the principal amount.

anchor.surface_text: From the date of the suit till the date of the final decree i.e. April 25. 1945, the appellants will only be entitled to simple interest at the rate of five per cent per annum on the principal amount advanced

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree binding per s.8(3) but subject to s.9(1) overriding higher interest rates from suit date.

holdings.text: From the date of the final decree, the mortgagee is entitled to simple interest at 5% per annum only on the principal amount.

anchor.surface_text: Further from the date of the final decree also the appellants will be entitled to simple interest at the rate of five per cent per annum on the principal amount only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent application of s.9(1) to post-decree ongoing liability; no compound or excess interest.

holdings.text: Any payments made after the date of the suit are to be adjusted first towards interest at 5% per annum simple, with excess reducing the principal.

anchor.surface_text: Any payments made after the date of the suit will be adjusted first towards interest at the rate of five per cent per annum simple and any payment made in excess thereof will go to reduce the principal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical adjustment under s.9(1) for post-suit payments in calculating remaining liability.

holdings.text: The mortgagee is entitled to costs of the suit as decreed, but no interest on such costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants will also be entitled to the costs of the suit which was decreed in their favour, but there will be no interest on such costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Costs decreed binding per s.8(3); s.9(1) limits interest to principal only.

holdings.text: The provisions of s.9(1) are retrospective only to the extent of governing the calculation of interest on liability still due when the claim is made, without reopening completed past payments.

anchor.surface_text: The Competent Officer held that though the provisions of s. 9 1 were retrospective to a certain extent they could not be stretched to mean that if a mortgagee had already realised interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual limits on retrospectivity absent explicit reopening provision.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; writ petition allowed; Appellate Officer's order set aside; Competent Officer's order varied with directions for calculating mortgage liability at 5% simple interest from suit date onwards, without reopening pre-suit accounts.
directions: Pre-suit payments (before December 11, 1939) at contractual rate or less do not reduce principal even if exceeding 5%.
Simple interest at 5% per annum on principal from suit date (December 11, 1939) to final decree (April 25, 1945).
Simple interest at 5% per annum on principal from final decree date onwards.
Post-suit payments adjusted first towards 5% simple interest, excess towards principal.
Appellants entitled to costs of the mortgage suit, without interest on such costs.
Account to be made up accordingly; Competent Officer to proceed under S. 10(b) or (c).

Section 3 of Evacuee Interest (Separation) Act addresses the interpretive issue under s.9(1) on reopening mortgage, as it contains or interacts with the non-obstante mechanism subject to reading down.
The holding that the Competent Officer is bound by civil court decrees (except ex parte post-14.8.1947) is grounded in the terms of Section 8(3) as described.

Section 8(3) explicitly provides that civil court decrees (with specified exceptions) are binding on the Competent Officer, directly addressing the issue of whether such decrees bind the Competent Officer.

Non-obstante clause, which overrides contrary provisions in decrees but limited to future, addresses the issue of whether s.9(1) requires reopening mortgage accounts from the date of mortgage, as broad reading could override past decree calculations while narrow avoids rewriting past.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from a consideration of these provisions that the Competent Officer is bound by the decree of a civil court except an ex parte decree passed after August 14, 1947 in respect of a mortgage subject to the provisions of ss. 9 and 10.
We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie therefore in the absence of such a provision it cannot be assumed that the legislature intended that a mortgage transaction should be reopened from the date of the mortgage and accounts taken afresh and anything paid in excess of five per cent per annum simple interest applied towards reduction of the principal amount.
We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a

edges.explanation: Holding constrains broad application of Section 3 by not allowing pre-suit payments to reduce principal, enabling constitutional/narrower interpretation without rewriting.
Holding preserving pre-suit principal calculation supports the narrower interpretation of non-obstante clause as limited to future liability, avoiding rewrite of past.
Holding that pre-suit payments at contractual rate do not reduce principal directly addresses and resolves the issue against full reopening and fresh accounts from mortgage date.

anchor.surface_text: Any amount paid before the date of the suit i.e. December 11, 1939, provided it is not more than the contractual rate of interest though it may be above five per cent per annum simple will not go to reduce the principal amount.
We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a

From the date of the suit till the date of the final decree i.e. April 25. 1945, the appellants will only be entitled to simple interest at the rate of five per cent per annum on the principal amount advanced
We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a
Further from the date of the final decree also the appellants will be entitled to simple interest at the rate of five per cent per annum on the principal amount only.
We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a

Any payments made after the date of the suit will be adjusted first towards interest at the rate of five per cent per annum simple and any payment made in excess thereof will go to reduce the principal.
We therefore allow the appeal. The writ petition is allowed and the order of the Appellate Officer is set aside and the order of the Competent Officer varied in the manner indicated a
